Asian Development Outlook 2012

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  As a flagship publication of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the Asian Development 
Outlook (ADO) has become an important vehicle for enhancing ADB’s reputation as a credible 
and authoritative source of knowledge about Asia and the Pacific. The report’s analysis provides 
insights  into  the  economic  issues  faced  by  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  and  appropriate  policy 
responses. Its content informs ADB Management opinion and guides institutional views about 
the region’s macroeconomic prospects and important development issues. The production of 
the ADO has been regularly supported by technical assistance (TA) funding.1 The objectives, 
scope, and activities to be covered by the regional TA are in Appendix 1.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The TA Strategic Forum 2008 recognized the important role that flagship publications 
such as the ADO play in monitoring the major economic issues and trends of ADB's developing 
member  countries  (DMCs).  By  regularly  providing  comprehensive  analysis  on  evolving 
developments in DMCs, the ADO provides a basis for understanding the key drivers of, and 
constraints on, economic growth—a critical element for inclusive economic growth, which is one 
of the priority research areas under Strategy 2020.3 Also, under the new streamlined business 
processes, the ADO has been established as the main reference for the economic assessment 
and outlook section of the country partnership strategy.  
 
3.  In addition to the country-by-country and regional economic analyses, the ADO in its 
recent issues has featured timely topics on rebalancing growth, macroeconomic management 
beyond the global financial crisis, and South–South economic links. These are all important 
issues that have been brought to the fore in the wake of the recent global financial crisis. 
Discussion of these topics has important policy implications for developing Asia in sustaining 
long-term growth in the face of global uncertainties.  
 
4.  To address one of the development agendas of Asia and the Pacific as envisioned in 
Strategy 2020, the theme chapter of ADO 2012 will analyze issues relating to equality of 
opportunities and inclusive growth. This is of particular value since evidence suggests that 
developing Asia’s high economic growth rates in the past two decades have not been inclusive, 
i.e., the benefits of growth have not been widely shared, with the incomes of the rich rising much 
faster than those of the poor.4 Bridging the gap between Asia’s rich and poor, both in terms of 
income and non-income opportunities, will be pivotal in sustaining Asia’s growth. This research 
is in support of an initiative of the Economics and Research Department (ERD) to operationalize 
inclusive growth to inform policy making in DMCs. The preliminary results can also be an 
important input into the upcoming Asian Development Fund replenishment discussions. For the 
ADO 2012 Update, the theme topic will focus on the services sector. It will examine if the sector 
can provide an alternative source of employment in Asia’s middle-income countries5 in the face

of declining labor demand in the manufacturing sector. ERD will study how services can be 
made more open and tradable to allow the sector to contribute to Asia’s future growth. 
 
5.  ERD must work continuously to improve the analytical rigor and policy relevance of the 
report if it is to remain a credible, independent source of knowledge and information about Asia 
and the Pacific. The rising profile of the ADO has also highlighted the need to strengthen the 
methods used to derive the global baseline assumptions and country forecasts. Activities will 
include conducting  applied  and  policy research on  the  issues  of inclusive  growth  and  the 
services sector in developing Asia, building and sustaining capacity in macroeconomic modeling, 
acquiring  new  sources  of  information,  and  strengthening  peer  review.  High-quality  editing 
services are also crucial to ensure that the ADO’s key messages are communicated clearly and 
effectively.  
 
6.  To ensure that the messages and policy recommendations of the ADO reach the target 
audience, the launch and outreach activities must be carefully planned to make the ADO more 
effective.  There  is  a  huge  demand  for  an  Asian  voice,  and  disseminating  the  messages 
emanating from the ADO effectively can provide that.  
 
7.  The ADO is one of the most frequently downloaded publications from ADB’s website.6 It 
is directly or indirectly the source of much international and national news commentary that 
features analysis, views, and opinions from ADB. Thus, a concerted effort to produce a high-
quality publication is vital to elevate the publication’s profile and to ensure its relevance and 
usefulness in policy dialogues and formulation in ADB DMCs. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA will support activities that influence the intellectual environment within which 
authorities in developing Asia and the Pacific formulate economic policies. ADO 2012 and its 
update will provide in-depth, relevant, and timely assessments of the region’s economy and, at 
the same time, analyze the issue of inclusive growth in the context of equality of opportunities 
and the development of the services sector in developing Asia. Analyses from the publication 
will provide important empirical facts and policy recommendations that can promote ADB as an 
independent and authoritative source of knowledge about Asia and the Pacific. Appendix 2 
contains the draft contents pages of ADO 2012 and ADO 2012 Update.  
 
9.  The TA will support the further development and refinement of analytical methods to 
supplement ADB’s short- and medium-term country economic monitoring and reporting. This will 
strengthen the economic underpinnings of country programs and strategies for the DMCs, 
thereby creating better-informed and better-designed economic policies and enhancing ADB’s 
country assistance. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The main outputs of the TA will be the two publications: ADO 2012 and ADO 2012 
Update.  The  following  key  activities  will  be  supported  by  the  TA:  preparing  background 
                                                 
6  From 2006 to 2011, the ADO and ADO Update have consistently ranked among the top ADB downloads from the 
month of launch until the following year. At the time of their launches, the ADO and ADO Update have continued to 
generate significant coverage from both global and regional top-tier media, such as the Financial Times, the Asian 
Wall Street Journal, and the International Herald Tribune.

3 
analytical  papers,  capacity  building  on  macroeconomic  modeling,  further  developing  and 
refining analytical methods, drafting ADO content, economic and copyediting, preparing and 
laying out materials for publication, and disseminating key results and policy messages. Some 
activities to support initiatives to build capacity for macroeconomic modeling, generating growth 
projections, and monitoring markets will be supported by the TA. This will be linked to a bigger 
initiative within ERD that aims to build a ―modeling culture‖ within ADB, and would include 
economists in the regional departments, especially those involved in the preparation of the 
country chapters, and possibly ADB’s Office of Regional Economic Integration. Several activities 
for the preparation of ADO 2013 will also be supported under the TA.  
 
11.  Background research papers to provide a solid empirical and analytical foundation for 
ADO content will be produced under the TA. These papers will supplement the research work of 
ADB’s Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division (ERMF) on the selected theme topics, 
analyzing issues and policy implications for the DMCs covered. An advisory group consisting of 
about four leading researchers will be formed to provide direction and guidance on the research 
topics  for  both  ADO  2012  and  ADO  2012  Update.  The  advisory  group  will  meet  (via 
videoconference)  thrice  in  the  course  of  preparing  the  background  papers  (inception  and 
brainstorming, midterm, and finalization meetings).  
  
12.  Workshops and conferences will be organized as part of ADO preparation to strengthen 
the content. The writers’ workshop will focus on macroeconomic analysis of current issues, 
growth accounting, economic projections and macroeconomic modeling, and effective writing 
skills, which will target selected economists and national staff in regional departments and 
resident missions who are responsible for writing the country chapters. One of the objectives of 
the workshop on effective writing is to equip writers with the skills needed to craft high-quality 
country chapters. This will also impart skills that are of broader relevance for economic and 
sector work, which underpins country strategies. The conferences will focus on the reports’ 
theme chapters. Distinguished economists from the region will be invited to discuss initial drafts 
of the background papers to improve the analytical rigor and policy relevance of the theme 
chapters. 
 
13.  To ensure accuracy, coherence, and consistency in approach across the different parts 
of the ADO, high-quality editing services are required. Economic and copyediting activities will 
be  provided  by  international consultants  working  under the  direction  of the  assistant chief 
economist of ERMF.  
 
14.  In collaboration with Department of External Relations (DER), the reports will be widely 
disseminated. The initial media launch will be followed by presentations co-hosted by ADB 
development partners within and outside Asia and the Pacific. Outreach will also include more 
analytical discussions of the issues in partnership with academic institutions and think tanks. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,000,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The cost estimates 
and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency responsible for implementing and monitoring the TA. 
Given the high institutional profile of the ADO, the chief economist will report to the vice-

4   
president for Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development, and the President at 
critical points in the publications’ preparation. The TA is expected to start in September 2011 
and be completed by March 2013. 
 
17.  The  production  of a  high-quality ADO  will  be a  joint  effort of  ERD (led  by ERMF) 
economists, country economists of the regional departments and resident missions, national 
experts, international consultants, and economics editors. As in previous years, ERMF will seek 
the cooperation of the regional departments to coordinate with the resident missions on the 
preparation of the country chapters.   
 
18.  The  ADO  will  require  20  person-months  of  international  consultancy  resources  for 
economists who will prepare the background papers and analyses on the issue of equality of 
opportunity and inclusive growth, and provide support as part of the advisory group. In addition, 
the  TA  will  require  an  estimated  20  person-months  of  international  consultants’  time  for 
economic and technical editing of ADO manuscripts before final publication of ADO 2012 and 
ADO 2012 Update. Three person-months of national economic consultants’ time will also be 
required to assist in conducting research on different macroeconomic topics, and another 13 
person-months will be needed for the desktop publishing and graphic design requirements of 
the publication. Consultants will be hired as individuals7 or by partnering with a highly reputable 
international economic policy research institute. Resource persons will also be engaged to 
conduct  training  on  macroeconomics  and  economic  forecasting  and  may  also  serve  as 
discussants  during  the  workshops.  Consultants  and  resource  persons  will  be  engaged  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The outline terms of reference for the consultants and resource persons are in Appendix 
4.   
 
19.  The TA will finance the procurement of information and knowledge services, such as 
subscription to macroeconomic data providers (e.g., Bloomberg), as may be required to support 
relevant and up-to-date content. Equipment, such as computers and software to support the 
macroeconomic modeling work, will be purchased by ADB in accordance with its Procurement 
Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  in  coordination  with  the  Office  of 
Information Systems and Technology and Office of Administrative Services, where applicable. 
Upon the completion of the TA, the equipment will remain with ADB as it will be used in 
implementing subsequent ADO TA. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance 
with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 
 
20.  ADO workshops will be conducted to review and discuss the initial country chapters and 
background papers prepared for the ADO. These are tentatively scheduled for November and 
December 2011 and June 2012 at ADB headquarters. Annotated outlines and storylines of 
country  chapters  will  be  presented  during  the  November  workshop,  while  theme  chapter 
background papers for ADO 2012 will be discussed in the December workshop. The ADO 2012 
Update background materials will be discussed during the June workshop. The TA will also 
cover the travel expenses of selected resident mission staff who will be participating in the 
workshops as resource persons. 
 
21.  The TA will support the dissemination activities of ERD and DER. The major results and 
key policy messages emerging from the ADO 2012 and ADO 2012 Update will be disseminated 
                                                 
7  The consultants will be hired as individuals as the TA will require rapid mobilization of the editorial consultants and 
will involve independent studies where the consultant’s experience and qualification are the primary considerations.

5 
to  the  media,  DMC  policy  makers,  and  academic  communities.  The  media  launch  and 
subsequent  road  shows  will  be  undertaken  by  ERD  in  coordination  with  DER.  Separate 
launches will be undertaken by resident missions in selected DMCs in coordination with their 
regional departments and DER. Roundtable discussions and workshops in different academic 
and economic institutions will also be conducted to reach a wider audience. Both ADO 2012 and 
ADO 2012 Update will be featured on the ADB website and copies, either in print or on CD-
ROMs, will be distributed worldwide. The TA may also support the translation of the ADO into 
other languages, as may be required, to support dissemination activities in selected DMCs. This 
will be arranged by regional departments in coordination with the concerned resident missions 
and DER. 
 
22.  ERMF will closely monitor the work under the TA to ensure its effective implementation. 
ERD researchers will review the work of consultants engaged to verify that tasks are completed 
in accordance with the terms of reference, and that draft reports are delivered on time. Peer 
review of papers within ADB and, if possible, by other research and academic institutions will 
also be used as a tool to evaluate the quality and depth of analysis of the research papers. The 
assistant chief economist at ERMF will set the production schedule, assure that adequate staff 
are assigned, and be responsible for meeting the deadlines for the timely printing and delivery 
of publications. The success of the dissemination activities will be monitored through web 
download statistics and media monitoring reports provided by DER. 
 
23.  Evaluation of outputs and outcomes will also be done to help measure the success of 
the TA. ERMF postmortem evaluation of the overall ADO process will be conducted to identify 
strengths and weaknesses as well as areas for improvement that will serve as inputs for the 
next ADO. In fact, suggestions at the recent postmortem discussions among ERMF staff and 
country chapter authors will be utilized to improve the process for the preparation of country 
chapters. Reports and back-to-office reports on the conduct of the ADO and ADO Update 
launches will also be reviewed to gather feedback on the publications and learn lessons from 
them. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION   
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for the Asian Development Outlook 2012, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants  
1.  Economics  consultants  (international,  18  person-months).  The  consultants  should 
have excellent working experience in general macroeconomics and a good knowledge of the 
developing member country economies. Under the direct supervision of Macroeconomics and 
Finance Research Division (ERMF) staff, the consultants will 
(i)  prepare background and analytical papers on particular aspects of the theme 
chapters, as may be assigned; 
(ii)  present research findings and participate actively in the workshops; 
(iii)  revise and finalize working papers for publication; 
(iv)  review and provide comments on the theme chapter; and  
(v)  perform  all  other  functions  and  responsibilities  as  may  be  assigned  by  the 
assistant chief economist of ERMF. 
 
2.  Advisory  experts  (international,  2  person-months).  Leading  researchers  and 
academicians in the economics field will be engaged to constitute an advisory group to provide 
direction and guidance on Asian Development Outlook (ADO) research work on the theme 
topics. The experts will 
(i)  participate in the brainstorming meetings and provide advice on the outline of the 
proposed background papers;  
(ii)  provide  critical  comments  at  the  various  stages  of  the  preparation  of  the 
background papers; and 
(iii)  as may be necessary, participate as resource persons in the workshops and 
conferences. 
 
B.  Editors  
3.  Economics editors (international, 14 person-months). Economics editors with extensive 
experience in economic editing of economic publications will be engaged to ensure high quality of 
publications. Under the  direct supervision  of the  assistant chief  economist  of ERMF  and  in 
consultation with other Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff in the Economics and Research 
Department (ERD) involved in preparing and reviewing the country chapters or preparing the 
theme  chapters  for  ADO  2012  and  ADO  2012  Update,  the  economics  editors  will  edit  the 
manuscripts  for  consistency  and  economic  content.  The  editors  will  assist  in  preparing  the 
highlights (English version) of the publication. The editors will also ensure that all the data in the 
publication are based on the most recent information available as of the specified cutoff date. In 
particular, the economics editors will 
(i)  edit the ADO for consistency with economic theory as well as empirical evidence; 
(ii)  edit the ADO for internal consistency, balanced coverage, and degree of detail 
and precision; 
(iii)  check the report for structure, content, and format to ensure that it conforms to 
the prescribed requirements for the ADO; 
(iv)  review the validity and accuracy of information, tables, and charts included in the 
write-up; 
(v)  confer with ERMF staff regarding gaps in the write-up, important questions, and 
needed revisions; 
(vi)  assist in preparing the publication highlights; 
(vii)  help prepare the key messages and review press releases for the ADO; and

Appendix 4  13 
(viii)  perform  all  other  functions  and  responsibilities  as  may  be  assigned  by  the 
assistant chief economist of ERMF. 
  
4.  Manuscript editor (international, 6 person-months). A manuscript editor will be engaged 
to ensure language consistency and that the publications conform to ADB style and usage. Under 
the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of ERMF, and in coordination with relevant 
ERMF staff, the manuscript editor will 
(i)  edit  the  ADO  including  (a)  rewriting,  reorganizing,  or  shortening  the  text  to 
improve its logical structure and sharpen the arguments; (b) simplifying technical 
language, eliminating jargon, and introducing definitions so that the chapters can 
be understood by an educated nonspecialist; (c) coordinating with the authors 
and economics editors to make explicit connections among ideas and to illustrate 
complex concepts; (d) cutting or editing redundant passages and simplifying long 
complicated  sentences;  (e)  smoothening  or  writing  transitions  between 
paragraphs and sections; and (f) suggesting additional materials (e.g., boxes, 
tables, figures) that would make the publication more reader-friendly;  
(ii)  check the manuscript for consistency and accuracy including (a) checking factual 
errors (e.g., whether correct names of institutions and other entities are used; 
checking major statements of fact on leading websites, where practical); and (b) 
highlighting  data  inconsistencies  (e.g.,  alerting  ERMF  national  officers  to 
discrepancies  in  data  among  text,  tables,  and  charts  for  their  chapters  and 
ensuring that queries are addressed, and ensuring that the benchmarks are 
referred to coherently in the publication); 
(iii)  copyedit  all  parts  of  the reports  in conformity with  ADB’s  editorial style  and 
usage; 
(iv)  smooth out the entire structure of the publications to make them readable with a 
consistent logical flow; 
(v)  ensure, to a degree possible, consistency of language style in all parts of the 
publication; 
(vi)  edit tables and figures; 
(vii)  ensure that subheads are consistent and logical; 
(viii)  check references to tables, figures, appendixes, bibliographies, and parts of the 
text; 
(ix)  edit notes to make sure that the text references are correct; 
(x)  supervise the encoding of corrections as well as incorporation of tables, charts, 
and boxes; 
(xi)  prepare the table of contents, definition of terms, and list of acronyms; 
(xii)  edit all dissemination materials including press releases, speeches, questions 
and answers, key messages, and presentation slides;  
(xiii)  liaise with the typesetter designated by ERMF to ensure that all editorial marks 
and/or comments as well as tables, charts, and boxes are incorporated into the 
typeset manuscript, and that the manuscript is ready for submission for final 
printing; and 
(xiv)  perform all other functions as may be assigned by the assistant chief economist 
of ERMF. 
 
C.  Resource Persons (0.6 person-months) 
 
5.  Resource persons (from both local institutions and offices of international organizations 
in Asia and the Pacific) with knowledge of the theme chapter topics will also be engaged to act 
as discussants during the ADO theme conferences.

14  Appendix 4 
 
 
D.  National Consultants  
 
6.  Economics  consultants  (national,  3  person-months). The  consultants  should  have 
excellent working experience in general economics. Under the direct supervision of ERMF staff, 
the  consultants  will  assist  in  the  economic  research  work  of  ERD  and  undertake  general 
economic research. In particular, the consultants will 
(i)  conduct research  on issues  related  to macroeconomic  development, growth, 
trade and investment, human capital development, and long-term employment 
generation in Asia and the Pacific; 
(ii)  support country economic analyses; 
(iii)  contribute to the preparation of the ADO and its update; 
(iv)  update the ADO data sheet; and 
(v)  undertake ad hoc research and other assignments as may be assigned by the 
assistant chief economist of ERMF. 
 
7.  Desktop publishing specialist and graphic designer (national, 13 person-months). 
The consultant(s) must be skilled in working with Adobe InDesign, Adobe Illustrator, Adobe 
Photoshop, Microsoft Word, and Microsoft Excel. He and/or she will typeset and proofread the 
text, tables, charts, and all graphic elements of the publication from the preliminary draft to the 
final copy and produce the high-resolution PDF file before forwarding to the external printer 
(including refining its web version). In particular, the consultant will  
(i)  lay out the ADO; 
(ii)  reformat tables and charts of the ADO based on corrections received from ERMF 
staff and consultants; 
(iii)  encode corrections in the main text based on corrections received from ERMF 
staff and consultants; 
(iv)  prepare the final layout of the ADO; 
(v)  encode final text and graphical corrections; 
(vi)  deliver the web-ready and pre-flighted consolidated PDF of the publication; and 
(vii)  perform other related tasks as assigned by the assistant chief economist of 
ERMF.
